ImguBox

Published: May 20th 2015 • 536 words • 2 min read

ImguBox connects Imgur with Dropbox and syncs your favorites.
You find the project here here.

In the early months of 2015 Imgur released their iOS app. After hours waisted in the endless stream of cat pictures, funny gifs and interesting stories, I thought it would be great to store my favorited albums in my Dropbox. Just for convenience.

I often discovered huge albums with wallpapers or interesting stuff about food which I wanted to store for further usage.
And that‚Äôs how ‚ÄúImguBox‚Äù was born.

With my favorite PHP Framework, Laravel 5 I quickly scaffolded a simple app, where you can sign up for an account and setup your Imgur and Dropbox account. That‚Äôs it!

The struggles

The idea sounded pretty simple. Everytime a user marks an album as their favorite, the corresponding images and description should be stored in a Dropbox account. Simple, right?.

But there is one small thing which bothered me. The Imgur API returns a collection of albums a user has favorited. So everytime ImguBox would to it‚Äôs Magic‚Ñ¢, it would fetch all albums and store it in Dropbox. And that‚Äôs bad.
Let‚Äôs say the app has 100 users. Every user has 100 favorites. If ImguBox fetches those favorites every hour, it has to fetch 10‚Äô000 albums (and each album contains maybe 50 images) every hour. For know I‚Äôve implemented a simple solution. A database records every parsed image for a given user. Now, when we fetch the favorites from Imgur we substract the already processed albums from the collection and proceed with a much smaller collection.

But now the good news. Imgur is working on webhooks. This would eliminate the database overhead and the app would be even smaller and simpler.

What I‚Äôve learned from this project

  • Push queues are awesome! They let you move time intensive tasks into the background. Due to it‚Äôs nature, the processing of uploading favorites to Dropbox is timeconsuming I‚Äôve used queues to process them asynchronously.
    For like half a year I struggled with unterstanding how those queues work, what the differences between push and pull is and how I can use them in a project. Now I got the hang of them and I don‚Äôt want to miss them anymore.
  • Integration Tests are great for small projects like this. Thanks to Jeffrey Way from laracasts, there is a great package for Laravel. I watched some screencasts, wrote some tests and now I can be certain that the cruical parts of the app work.
  • Don‚Äôt rush! I‚Äôve written the core code of the app in an afternoon. I immediately thought "Okay, let‚Äôs deploy it. Someone will probably like it.", but then I reallized I should do some deeper tests and then all kinds of exceptions where thrown. I went back to the drawing board and I‚Äôve rewritten the app.
    Now the app should handle most common errors well and I will be informed if something goes wrong.
